_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY
Natural Selection Foods utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment prior to startup and during operations.  These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases.  The equipment is reviewed by onsite personnel, and certified refrigeration contractors as required.

Initial emergency response is provided by onsite personnel.  Onsite personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response.  First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release. No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other onsite personnel. Emergency response for a major release event will be provided by local fire and police departments with mutual aide response. The refrigeration contractor would also be on-call to provide emergency response.

Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees.  Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years.

DESCRIPTION OF SOURCE AND SUBSTANCE HANDLED
The Natural Selection Foods facility is located at 1721 San Juan Highway in San Juan Bautista, California. This facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in their precooling, cold rooms and process water chilling operations. Fresh produce is brought from the fields and cooled to remove field heat.  The produce is then stored in a cold storage warehouse.
The equipment for warehouse cooling consists of portable and permanently installed equipment. The main refrigeration system configuration includes: two Low Pressure Recirculating unit with ammonia pumps, cold room evaporators, various safety equipment including two refrigerant discharge diffusion tanks, four compressors with

a common thermosyphon, four evaporative cooling condenser and a high-pressure receiver.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
An offsite consequence analysis for an ammonia release was performed to determine impacts to neighboring schools, businesses, residences, recreation areas, and historical and environmentally sensitive sites.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The accidental release prevention program consists of maintenance, emergency response, and regular training.  A thorough review of the system including a ?What If? Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed prior to initial startup. Equipment corrections and updates were made for those items determined to have the highest potential for off-site releases. Safety and equipment operational training will be conducted on a yearly basis and will include equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of general Risk Management Plan procedures, review of Business Response Plan procedures, and evacuation procedures. Refrigeration equipment will be reviewed as required, and as new equipment is placed in operation onsite.
Administrative controls limit the amount of ammonia in the system. A diffusion tank is a system-wide mitigation measure added to the facility. Mitigation measures are not considered for every release scenario. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
According to Pride of Natural Selection Foods Personnel, since startup there have been no releases of anhydrous ammonia resulting in reportable quantities or injuries.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Natural Selection Foods has a written Emergency Response Program. The facility implemented the State and County mandated emergency response plan (AKA Business Response Plan), which outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release response as well as general facility response.

PLANNED SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS
Additional risk reduction measures may be implemented to further reduce the potential for an accidental release. These measures may include instal

lation of upgraded piping and equipment supports, installation of equipment labeling, and implementation of program aimed specifically at the maintenance, training, and emergency response procedures for the ammonia based refrigeration equipment.
